1: bypassed

PLL decimal frequency division control

1: integral frequency-division mode
pll_dacpd[24]
PLL test signal control
0: normal operating mode
1: power-down mode
pll_foutpostdivpd[23]
Power-down control for the PLL FOUTPOSTDIV output
0: normal clock output
1: no clock output
pll_fout4phasepd[22]
Power-down control for the PLL FOUT0?4 output
0: normal clock output
1: no clock output
pll_foutvcopd[21]
Power-down control for the PLL FOUTVCO output
0: normal clock output
1: no clock output
pll_pd[20]
PLL power-down control
0: normal operating mode
1: power-down mode
pll_refdiv[17:12]
Frequency divider of the PLL reference clock
pll_fbdiv[11:0]
Integral frequency multiplier factor of the PLL

RegisterGroup.name: PERI_CRG103
RegisterGroup.description: a Demod clock and soft reset control register.

Member.name: demod_fsclk_div
Member.description:
Relationship between the bit clock BCLK and the sampling clock FS
000: FS is BCLK divided by 16.
001: FS is BCLK divided by 32.
010: FS is BCLK divided by 48.
011: FS is BCLK divided by 64.
100: FS is BCLK divided by 128.
101: FS is BCLK divided by 256.
Other values: FS is BCLK divided by 8.

Member.name: demod_bclk_div
Member.description:
Relationship between the main clock MCLK and the bit clock BCLK
0000: BCLK is MCLK divided by 1.
0001: BCLK is MCLK divided by 3.
0010: BCLK is MCLK divided by 2.
0011: BCLK is MCLK divided by 4.
0100: BCLK is MCLK divided by 6.
0101: BCLK is MCLK divided by 8.
0110: BCLK is MCLK divided by 12.
0111: BCLK is MCLK divided by 16.
1000: BCLK is MCLK divided by 24.
1001: BCLK is MCLK divided by 32.
1010: BCLK is MCLK divided by 48.
1011: BCLK is MCLK divided by 64.
Other values: BCLK is MCLK divided by 8.

Member.name: otp_ctrl_vdac
Member.description:
Four ADAC channels enable
Bits 15?12 correspond to channels 3?0 respectively.
When the OTP value is 0, channels are controlled by the VDP register by default.
When the OTP value is 1, the enable bit of the corresponding channel is forcibly set to 0, that is, the channel is forcibly powered off.

RegisterGroup.name: SC_LOCKEN
RegisterGroup.description:
a write protection control register. This register provides a write protection mechanism for the following key registers of the system controller:
  • SC_CTRLSC_SYSRESWhen the value 0x4F50_454E is written to SC_LOCKEN, the write protection function of the preceding key registers is disabled. In this case, the attributes of the key registers are changed to writable, that is, these registers can be written. When any value instead of 0x4F50_454E is written to SC_LOCKEN, the attributes of the key registers are changed to read-only. In this case, writing these registers has no effect.You can check whether the key registers are write-protected by reading SC_LOCKEN. For example:
  • If the value 0x756E_4C4F is returned, write protection is disabled, and you can write to the key registers.
  • If the value 0x4C4F_434B is returned, write protection is enabled, and writing to these registers has no effect.The reset value of SC_LOCKEN is 0x756E_4C4F, indicating that the key registers are not write-protected.

Member.name: sc_locken
Member.description: Write protection indicator of key system registers. For details, see the function description of SC_LOCKEN.

RegisterGroup.name: INT_STAT
RegisterGroup.description: an interrupt status register of processor X.

Member.name: int_stat
Member.description:
Status of the masked interrupts for each DMAC channel. Bit[15:0] map to channels 15?0.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated. The interrupt request may be an error interrupt or a transfer completion interrupt.

RegisterGroup.name: INT_TC1
RegisterGroup.description: a channel transfer completion interrupt status register of processor X.

Member.name: int_tc1
Member.description:
Status of the masked channel transfer completion interrupts for each DMAC channel. Bit[15:0] map to channels 15?0.
0: No transfer completion interrupt is generated.
1: A transfer completion interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: INT_TC2
RegisterGroup.description: a linked list node transfer completion interrupt status register of processor X.

Member.name: int_tc2
Member.description:
Status of the masked linked list node transfer completion interrupts for each DMAC channel. Bit[15:0] map to channels 15?0.
0: No transfer completion interrupt is generated.
1: A transfer completion interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: INT_ERR1
RegisterGroup.description: a configuration error interrupt status register of processor X.

Member.name: int_err1
Member.description:
Status of the masked configuration error interrupts for each DMA channel. Bit[15:0] map to channels 15?0.
0: No configuration error interrupt is generated.
1: A configuration error interrupt is generated.
This interrupt is generated in the following cases:
1. Account is set to 0.
2. The ID of the linked channel is that of the current channel.
3. The linked channel does not exist (this issue occurs only when the number of channels is less than 16).
4. When narrow transfer is supported, the reserved value of the burst size is configured.
5. The configured address is not aligned with the burst size during FIX transfer.
6. The reserved value of flow_ctrl is configured.
7. The reserved value of chain_en is configured.
8. The configuration error interrupt is generated when the previous issues occurs in the configuration for the linked list node.

RegisterGroup.name: INT_ERR2
RegisterGroup.description: a data transfer error interrupt status register of processor X.

Member.name: int_err2
Member.description:
Status of the masked data transfer error interrupts for each DMAC channel. Bit[15:0] map to channels 15?0.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: INT_ERR3
RegisterGroup.description: a linked list read error interrupt status register of processor X.

Member.name: int_err3
Member.description:
Status of the masked linked list read error interrupts for each DMA channel. Bit[15:0] map to channels 15?0.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: INT_TC1_RAW
RegisterGroup.description: a raw channel transfer completion interrupt status register.

Member.name: int_tc1_raw
Member.description:
Status of the raw channel transfer completion interrupts for each channel. Bit[15:0] map to channels 15?0.
When this register is read:
0: No channel transfer completion interrupt is generated.
1: A channel transfer completion interrupt is generated.
When this register is written:
1: The channel transfer completion interrupt is cleared.
0: The original value is retained.

1: A linked list node transfer completion interrupt is generated.
When this register is written:
1: The linked list node transfer completion interrupt is cleared.
0: The original value is retained.

RegisterGroup.name: SREQ
RegisterGroup.description: a single transfer request register.

Member.name: sreq
Member.description:
Whether to generate the DMA single transfer request
When this register is written:
0: no effect
1: A DMA single transfer request is generated. When the transfer is complete, the corresponding bit is cleared.
When this register is read:
0: The corresponding peripheral does not initiate a single transfer request.
1: The corresponding peripheral initiates a single transfer request.

RegisterGroup.name: LSREQ
RegisterGroup.description: a last single transfer request register.

Member.name: lsreq
Member.description:
Whether to generate the DMA last single transfer request
When this register is written:
0: no effect
1: A DMA last single transfer request is generated. When the transfer is complete, the corresponding bit is cleared.
When this register is read:
0: The corresponding peripheral does not initiate a last single transfer request.
1: The corresponding peripheral initiates a last single transfer request.

RegisterGroup.name: CH_STAT
RegisterGroup.description: a global DMA status register.

Member.name: ch_stat
Member.description:
DMAC channel enable
1: The corresponding DMAC channel is working.
0: The corresponding DMAC channel is not working.

RegisterGroup.name: SEC_CTRL
RegisterGroup.description: a DMA global security control register.

Member.name: intr_sec_ctrl
Member.description:
Interrupt security control (accessed by only secure operations)
0: Secure operations can access interrupt information of only secure channels. Secure interrupts are reported by using dma_intr, and non-secure interrupts are reported by using dma_intr_ns.
1: Secure operations can access information of all channels. Secure interrupts and non-secure interrupts are reported by using dma_intr. However, dma_intr_ns reports only non-secure interrupts.

Member.name: global_sec
Member.description:
Global register security control (accessed by only secure operations)
0: CH_PRI and DMA_CTRL can be accessed by only secure operations.
1: CH_PRI and DMA_CTRL can be accessed by both secure and non-secure operations.

RegisterGroup.name: DMA_CTRL
RegisterGroup.description: a DMA global control register.

Member.name: conf_out4
Member.description:
When the macro definition of the outstanding number is 8:
1: The outstanding number is 4.
0: The outstanding number is 8.
When the macro definition of the outstanding number is 4, this bit cannot be written. Bit 0 is read.
Note: Modification on the outstanding is valid only when all the channels are idle and the corresponding CH_STAT register is set to all 0s. Otherwise, the modification is invalid.

Member.name: halt_req
Member.description:
DMA HALT request configuration register
When this bit is read:
1: The DMA has received the HALT request but has not entered the HALT state.
0: The DMA has not received the HALT request or the DMA has entered the HALT state.
When this bit is written:
1: A DMA HALT request is initiated.
0: no effect. The original value is retained.

Member.name: halt_ack
Member.description:
Whether the DMA enters the HALT state
When this bit is read:
1: The DMA has entered the HALT state.
0: The DMA has not entered the HALT state.
When this bit is written:
1: The DMA HALT state is disabled.
0: no effect. The original value is retained.

RegisterGroup.name: CX_CURR_CNT0

Member.name: curr_b_count
Member.description: Number of remaining arrays in the current 2D transfer of channel X

Member.name: curr_a_count
Member.description: Number of remaining bytes in the current 1D transfer of channel X

RegisterGroup.name: CX_CURR_SRC_ADDR
RegisterGroup.description: a source address register of channel X.

Member.name: curr_src_addr
Member.description: Source address of the current transfer of channel X

RegisterGroup.name: CX_CURR_DES_ADDR
RegisterGroup.description: a destination address register of channel X.

Member.name: curr_des_addr
Member.description: Destination address of the current transfer of channel X

RegisterGroup.name: CX_LLI
RegisterGroup.description: a linked list address register of channel X.

Member.name: lli
Member.description:
Bit[31:5] of the address for the next linked list node of channel X. The linked list address must be 256-bit aligned.
When channel link is enabled, bit[11:8] indicates the ID of the next linked channel.

Member.name: chain_en
Member.description:
Channel link enable
00: Both the linked list link enable and the channel link enable are invalid.
01: The linked list link enable is invalid, but the channel link enable is valid.
10: The linked list link enable is valid, but the channel link enable is invalid.
11: reserved. A configuration error interrupt is reported if the reserved value is configured.

RegisterGroup.name: CX_BINDX
RegisterGroup.description: a 2D address offset configuration register of channel X.

Member.name: src_bsign
Member.description:
2D source address offset sign bit
1: negative
0: positive

Member.name: src_bindx
Member.description: 2D source address offset configuration, indicating the absolute value of the offset. Bit[31] is the sign bit.

Member.name: des_bsign
Member.description:
2D destination address offset sign bit
1: negative
0: positive

Member.name: des_bindx
Member.description: 2D destination address offset configuration, indicating the absolute value of the offset. Bit[15] is the sign bit.

RegisterGroup.name: CX_CINDX
RegisterGroup.description: a 3D address offset configuration register of channel X.

Member.name: src_csign
Member.description:
3D source address offset sign bit.
1: negative
0: positive

Member.name: src_cindx
Member.description: 3D source address offset configuration, indicating the absolute value of the offset. Bit[31] is the sign bit.

Member.name: des_csign
Member.description:
3D destination address offset sign bit
1: negative
0: positive

Member.name: des_cindx
Member.description: 3D destination address offset configuration, indicating the absolute value of the offset. Bit[15] is the sign bit.

RegisterGroup.name: CX_CNT1
RegisterGroup.description: a transfer length configuration register of channel X.

Member.name: c_count
Member.description:
3D transfer length configuration (1?65535)
It refers to the number of frames in a block. The value 0 indicates that there is no 3D transfer. The number of frames is c_count plus 1.

RegisterGroup.name: CX_CNT0
RegisterGroup.description: a transfer length configuration register of channel X.

Member.name: b_count
Member.description:
2D transfer length configuration (1–65535)
It refers to the number of arrays in a frame. The number of arrays in a frame is b_count plus 1.

Member.name: a_count
Member.description:
1D transfer length configuration (1?65535)
It refers to the least number of bytes in an array. A configuration error interrupt is reported when Acount is set to 0.

RegisterGroup.name: CX_SRC_ADDR
RegisterGroup.description: a source address register of channel X.

Member.name: src_addr
Member.description: Source address of channel X

RegisterGroup.name: CX_DES_ADDR
RegisterGroup.description: a destination address register of channel X.

Member.name: des_addr
Member.description: Destination address of channel X

RegisterGroup.name: CX_CONFIG
RegisterGroup.description: a configuration register of channel X.

Member.name: si
Member.description:
Source address increment configuration
0: The source address is not incremented.
1: The source address is incremented each time a data segment is transferred.
If the source device is a peripheral, the source address is not incremented. If the source device is a memory, the source address is incremented.

Member.name: di
Member.description:
Destination address increment configuration
0: The destination address is not incremented.
1: The destination address is incremented each time a data segment is transferred.
If the destination device is a peripheral, the destination address is not incremented. If the destination device is a memory, the destination address is incremented.

Member.name: smode
Member.description:
Source address increment mode
0: A-sync mode. 3D address offset is the interval between the start address for the last array in a frame and that for the first array in the next frame.
1: AB-sync mode. 3D address offset is the interval between the start address for the first array in a frame and that for the first array in the next frame.

Member.name: dmode
Member.description:
Destination address increment mode
0: A-sync mode. 3D address offset is the interval between the start address for the last array in a frame and that for the first array in the next frame.
1: AB-sync mode. 3D address offset is the interval between the start address for the first array in a frame and that for the first array in the next frame.

Member.name: sl
Member.description:
Burst length on the source side
0000: 1
0001: 2
...
1111: 16

Member.name: dl
Member.description:
Burst length on the destination side
0000: 1
0001: 2
...
1111: 16

Member.name: sw
Member.description:
Source data width
000: 8 bits
001: 16 bits
010: 32 bits
011: 64 bits
100: 128 bits
101: 256 bits
110 and 111: reserved

Member.name: dw
Member.description:
Destination data width
000: 8 bits
001: 16 bits
010: 32 bits
011: 64 bits
100: 128 bits
101: 256 bits
110 and 111: reserved

Member.name: peri
Member.description: Peripheral request signal. If the signal is sent from one memory to another memory, these bits are ignored. A maximum of 32 requests are supported. Therefore, bit 9 is not used. Bit[8:4] are used actually. The valid values of peri vary according to the valid number of peripheral requests in the request macro definition configuration for different peripherals. If the macro definition uses only 16 peripheral requests, the values from 0 to 15 for the peri field are valid. The values for the upper bits can be configured, but are ignored.

Member.name: flow_ctrl
Member.description:
Flow control type and transfer type
00: transfer between two memories, DMAC flow control.
01: transfer between a memory and a peripheral, DMAC flow control
10: transfer between a memory and a peripheral, peripheral flow control
11: reserved. A configuration error interrupt is reported if the reserved value is configured.

Member.name: itc_en
Member.description:
Linked list node transfer completion interrupt enable. This bit is used to configure whether to trigger a linked list node transfer completion interrupt after the current linked list node transfer is complete.
0: A linked list node transfer completion interrupt is not triggered after the current linked list node transfer is complete.
1: A linked list transfer completion interrupt is triggered after the current linked list node transfer is complete, but a linked list node transfer completion interrupt will not be triggered when the last linked list node transfer is complete.
Note: A channel transfer completion interrupt is reported when all linked list node transfers are complete no matter whether this bit is set to 0 or 1.

Member.name: ch_en
Member.description:
Current channel enable
Running status of the current channel (when this register is written)
0: disabled/reset
1: enabled
Status of the current channel (when this register is read)
0: The current channel stops running.
1: The current channel is running (The current channel is always enabled when the linked list transfer is enabled).

RegisterGroup.name: CX_AXI_CONF
RegisterGroup.description: an AXI special operation configuration register of channel X.

Member.name: awcache
Member.description: Cache type of the AXI bus write command, compliant with the AXI bus protocol

Member.name: awprot
Member.description: Protection type of the AXI bus write command, compliant with the AXI bus protocol

Member.name: awuser
Member.description:
Write sideband information of the ARM CPU ACP interface
Bit[4:1]: inner attribute bits
0000: strongly-ordered
0001: device
0011: normal memory non-cacheable
0110: write-through
0111: write-back no write allocate
1111: write-back write allocate
Bit[0]: shared bit

Member.name: arcache
Member.description: Cache type of the AXI bus read command, compliant with the AXI bus protocol

Member.name: arprot
Member.description: Protection type of the AXI bus read command, compliant with the AXI bus protocol

Member.name: aruser
Member.description:
Read sideband information of the ARM CPU ACP interface
Bit[4:1]: inner attribute bits
0000: strongly-ordered
0001: device
0011: normal memory non-cacheable
0110: write-through
0111: write-back no write allocate
1111: write-back write allocate
Bit[0]: shared bit

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER0_LOAD
RegisterGroup.description:
an initial count value register. It is used to set the initial count value of a timer. Each timer (timer 0–timer D) has one such register.When a timer is in periodic mode and the count value decreases to 0, the value of TIMERx_LOAD is reloaded to the counter. When a value is directly written to TIMERx_LOAD, the value of the current counter is changed to the written value at the next rising edge of the TIMCLK enabled by TIMCLKENx.NOTE
  • The minimum valid value written to TIMERx_LOAD is 1.
  • When 0 is written to TIMERx_LOAD, the dual-timer submodule immediately generates an interrupt.When a value is written to TIMERx_BGLOAD, the value of TIMERx_LOAD is overwritten, but the current value of the timer remains.If values are written to TIMERx_BGLOAD and TIMERx_LOAD before the rising edge of TIMCLK enabled by TIMCLKENx is reached, the value of the counter is changed to the written value of TIMERx_LOAD at the next rising edge. From then on, each time the counter decreases to 0, the last value written to TIMERx_BGLOAD or TIMERx_LOAD is reloaded.After TIMERx_BGLOAD and TIMERx_LOAD are written twice respectively, the written value of TIMERx_BGLOAD is returned when TIMERx_LOAD is read.

Member.name: timer0_load
Member.description: Initial count value of timer 0

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER1_LOAD
RegisterGroup.description:
an initial count value register. It is used to set the initial count value of a timer. Each timer (timer 0–timer D) has one such register.When a timer is in periodic mode and the count value decreases to 0, the value of TIMERx_LOAD is reloaded to the counter. When a value is directly written to TIMERx_LOAD, the value of the current counter is changed to the written value at the next rising edge of the TIMCLK enabled by TIMCLKENx.NOTE
  • The minimum valid value written to TIMERx_LOAD is 1.
  • When 0 is written to TIMERx_LOAD, the dual-timer submodule immediately generates an interrupt.When a value is written to TIMERx_BGLOAD, the value of TIMERx_LOAD is overwritten, but the current value of the timer remains.If values are written to TIMERx_BGLOAD and TIMERx_LOAD before the rising edge of TIMCLK enabled by TIMCLKENx is reached, the value of the counter is changed to the written value of TIMERx_LOAD at the next rising edge. From then on, each time the counter decreases to 0, the last value written to TIMERx_BGLOAD or TIMERx_LOAD is reloaded.After TIMERx_BGLOAD and TIMERx_LOAD are written twice respectively, the written value of TIMERx_BGLOAD is returned when TIMERx_LOAD is read.

Member.name: timer1_load
Member.description: Initial count value of timer 1

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER0_VALUE
RegisterGroup.description:
a current count value register. It provides the current value of the counter that is counting down.Each timer (timer 0–timer D) has one such register.After a value is written to TIMERx_LOAD, TIMERx_VALUE immediately reflects the newly loaded value of the counter in the PCLK domain without waiting for the next clock edge of the TIMCLK enabled by TIMCLKENx.NOTE
When a timer is in 16-bit mode, the upper 16 bits of the 32-bit TIMERx_VALUE are not automatically set to 0. If TIMERx_LOAD is never written after the timer is switched from 32-bit mode to 16-bit mode, the upper 16 bits of TIMERx_VALUE may be non-zero values.

Member.name: timer0_value
Member.description: Current count value of timer 0 that is counting down

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER1_VALUE
RegisterGroup.description:
a current count value register. It provides the current value of the counter that is counting down.Each timer (timer 0–timer D) has one such register.After a value is written to TIMERx_LOAD, TIMERx_VALUE immediately reflects the newly loaded value of the counter in the PCLK domain without waiting for the next clock edge of the TIMCLK enabled by TIMCLKENx.NOTE
When a timer is in 16-bit mode, the upper 16 bits of the 32-bit TIMERx_VALUE are not automatically set to 0. If TIMERx_LOAD is never written after the timer is switched from 32-bit mode to 16-bit mode, the upper 16 bits of TIMERx_VALUE may be non-zero values.

Member.name: timer0_value
Member.description: Current count value of timer 1 that is counting down

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER0_CONTROL
RegisterGroup.description:
a timer control register. Each timer (timer 0–timer D) has one such register.NOTE
When the periodic mode is selected, TIMERx_CONTROL[timermode] must be set to 1 and TIMERx_CONTROL[oneshot] must be set to 0.

Member.name: timeren
Member.description:
Timer enable
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: timermode
Member.description:
Timer count mode
0: free-running mode
1: periodic mode

Member.name: intenable
Member.description:
TIMERx_RIS interrupt mask
0: masked
1: not masked

Member.name: timerpre
Member.description:
Timer prescaling divider
00: no prescaling. That is, the clock frequency of the timer is divided by 1.
01: 4-level prescaling. That is, the clock frequency of the timer is divided by 16.
10: 8-level prescaling. That is, the clock frequency of the timer is divided by 256.
11: undefined. If this value is used, 8-level prescaling is considered. That is, the clock frequency of the timer is divided by 256.

Member.name: timersize
Member.description:
Counter select
0: 16-bit counter
1: 32-bit counter

Member.name: oneshot
Member.description:
Count mode
0: periodic mode or free-running mode
1: one-shot mode

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER1_CONTROL
RegisterGroup.description:
a timer control register. Each timer (timer 0–timer D) has one such register.NOTE
When the periodic mode is selected, TIMERx_CONTROL[timermode] must be set to 1 and TIMERx_CONTROL[oneshot] must be set to 0.

Member.name: timeren
Member.description:
Timer enable
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: timermode
Member.description:
Timer count mode
0: free-running mode
1: periodic mode

Member.name: intenable
Member.description:
TIMERx_RIS interrupt mask
0: masked

Member.name: timerpre
Member.description:
Timer prescaling divider
00: no prescaling. That is, the clock frequency of the timer is divided by 1.
01: 4-level prescaling. That is, the clock frequency of the timer is divided by 16.
10: 8-level prescaling. That is, the clock frequency of the timer is divided by 256.

Member.description:
Counter select

No written value is recorded in this register and no default reset value is defined.

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER0_BGLOAD
RegisterGroup.description: an initial count value register in periodic mode. Each timer (timer 0–timer D) has one such register.This register contains the initial count value of the timer. In periodic mode, this register is used to reload the initial count value when the count value of the timer decreases to 0.This register provides another way for accessing TIMERx_LOAD. After a value is written to TIMERx_BGLOAD, the timer, however, does not count starting from the new written value immediately.

Member.name: timer0bgload
Member.description:
Initial count value of timer 0
Note: This register differs from TIMER0_LOAD. For details, see the description of TIMERx_LOAD.

RegisterGroup.name: TIMER1_BGLOAD
RegisterGroup.description: an initial count value register in periodic mode. Each timer (timer 0–timer D) has one such register.This register contains the initial count value of the timer. In periodic mode, this register is used to reload the initial count value when the count value of the timer decreases to 0.This register provides another way for accessing TIMERx_LOAD. After a value is written to TIMERx_BGLOAD, the timer, however, does not count starting from the new written value immediately.

Member.name: timer1bgload
Member.description:
Initial count value of timer 1
Note: This register differs from TIMER1_LOAD. For details, see the description of TIMERx_LOAD.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_STAT
RegisterGroup.description: an interrupt status register. It shows the masked DMAC interrupt status. If certain bits of DMAC_INT_TC_STAT and DMAC_INT_ERR_STAT are masked at the same time, the corresponding bit of DMAC_INT_STAT is also masked. Each bit of DMAC_INT_STAT maps to one DMAC channel. When a bit is 1, an interrupt request is generated in the corresponding channel and the interrupt request may be an error interrupt or a transfer completion interrupt.

Member.name: int_stat
Member.description:
Masked interrupt status of each DMA channel. Bit[3:0] map to channels 3–0.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated. The interrupt request may be an error interrupt or a transfer completion interrupt.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_TC_STAT
RegisterGroup.description: a transfer completion interrupt status register. It shows the status of the masked transfer completion interrupts. The corresponding mask bit is DMAC_CX_CONFIG[itc], where X is the channel number ranging from 0 to 3. This register must work with the DMAC_INT_STAT register.

Member.name: int_tc_stat
Member.description:
Masked transfer completion interrupt status. Bit[3:0] map to channels 3–0.
0: No transfer completion interrupt is generated.
1: A transfer completion interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_TC_CLR
RegisterGroup.description: a transfer completion interrupt clear register. It is used to clear transfer completion interrupts.

Member.name: int_tc_clr
Member.description:
Transfer completion interrupt clear. Bit[3:0] map to channels 3–0.
0: not cleared
1: cleared

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_ERR_STAT
RegisterGroup.description: an error interrupt status register. It shows the masked error interrupt status. The corresponding mask bit is DMAC_CX_CONFIG[ie].

Member.name: int_err_stat
Member.description:
Masked error interrupt status. Bit[3:0] map to channels 3–0.
0: No error interrupt is generated.
1: An error interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_ERR_CLR
RegisterGroup.description: an error interrupt clear register. It is used to clear error interrupts.

Member.name: int_err_clr
Member.description:
Error interrupt clear. Bit[3:0] map to channels 3–0.
0: not cleared
1: cleared

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_RAW_INT_TC_STATUS
RegisterGroup.description: a raw transfer completion interrupt status register. It shows the status of the raw transfer completion interrupt of each channel.

Member.name: raw_int_tc_stat
Member.description:
Raw transfer completion interrupt status. Bit[3:0] map to channels 3–0.
0: No transfer completion interrupt is generated.
1: A transfer completion interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_RAW_INT_ERR_STATUS
RegisterGroup.description: a raw error interrupt status register. It shows the status of the raw error interrupt of each channel.

Member.name: raw_int_err_stat
Member.description:
Raw error interrupt status of each channel. Bit[3:0] map to channels 3–0.
0: No error interrupt is generated.
1: An error interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_ENBLD_CHNS
RegisterGroup.description: a channel enable register that shows the enabled channels.If a bit of DMAC_ENBLD_CHNS is 1, the corresponding channel is enabled. An enable bit in the DMAC_CX_CONFIG register determines whether a corresponding channel is enabled. If the DMA transfer over a channel is complete, the corresponding bit in the DMAC_ENBLD_CHNS register is cleared.

Member.name: enabled_channels
Member.description:
Channel enable. Bit[3:0] map to channels 3–0.
0: disabled
1: enabled

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SOFT_BREQ
RegisterGroup.description:
a burst request register for software. It is used for the software to control whether to generate a DMA burst request.Reading this register queries the device that is requesting the DMA burst transfer. This register and any peripheral each can generate a DMA request.NOTE
You are advised not to use a software DMA request and a hardware DMA request at the same time.

Member.name: soft_breq
Member.description:
Whether to generate DMA burst requests by the software
For details about the request corresponding to each bit, see Table 3-92.
When this register is written:
0: no effect
1: A DMA burst transfer request is generated. When the transfer is complete, the corresponding bit is cleared.
When this register is read:
0: The peripheral corresponding to the request signal DMACBREQ[15:0] does not send a DMA burst request.
1: The peripheral corresponding to the request signal DMACBREQ[15:0] is requesting a DMA burst transfer.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SOFT_SREQ
RegisterGroup.description:
a DMA single request register for software. It is used for the software to control whether to generate a DMA single transfer request.Reading this register queries the device that is requesting the DMA single transfer. This register and any of the 16 DMA request input signals of the DMAC each can generate a DMA request.NOTE
You are advised not to use a software DMA request and a hardware DMA request at the same time.

Member.name: soft_sreq
Member.description:
Whether to generate a DMA single transfer request by the software
For details about the request corresponding to each bit, see Table 3-92.
When this register is written:
0: no effect
1: A DMA single transfer request is generated. When the transfer is complete, the corresponding bit is cleared.
When this register is read:
0: The peripheral corresponding to the request signal DMACBREQ[15:0] does not send a DMA single request.
1: The peripheral corresponding to the request signal DMACBREQ[15:0] is requesting a single DMA transfer.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SOFT_LBREQ
RegisterGroup.description: a software last burst request register. It is used for the software to control whether to generate a DMA last burst transfer request.

Member.name: soft_lbreq
Member.description:
Whether to generate a DMA last burst transfer request by the software
For details about the request corresponding to each bit, see Table 3-92.
0: no effect
1: A DMA last burst transfer request is generated. When the transfer is complete, the corresponding bit is cleared.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SOFT_LSREQ
RegisterGroup.description: a software last single request register. It is used for the software to control whether to generate a DMA last single transfer request.

Member.name: soft_lsreq
Member.description:
Whether to generate a DMA last single transfer request by the software
For details about the request corresponding to each bit, see Table 3-92.
0: no effect
1: A DMA last single transfer request is generated. When the transfer is complete, the corresponding bit is cleared.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_CONFIG
RegisterGroup.description:
a configuration register for configuring the DMAC. You can change the endianness mode of the two master interfaces of the DMAC by writing to m1 (bit[1]) and m2 (bit[2]) of this register. After reset, the two master interfaces are set to little endian mode.NOTE
The two master interfaces work in little endian mode.

Member.name: m2
Member.description:
Endianness mode of master 2
0: little endian mode
1: big endian mode

Member.name: m1
Member.description:
Endianness mode of master 1
0: little endian mode
1: big endian mode

Member.name: e
Member.description:
DMAC enable
0: disabled
1: enabled

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SYNC
RegisterGroup.description: a synchronization register. It is used to enable or disable the synchronization logic provided for DMA request signals.

Member.name: dmac_sync
Member.description:
Sync logic enable for DMA request signals of the corresponding peripheral
For details about the request corresponding to each bit, see Table 3-92.
0: enabled
1: disabled

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_CX_SRC_ADDR
RegisterGroup.description:
a source address register. It shows the source addresses (sorted by byte) of the data to be transmitted.Its offset address is 0x100+X*0x20. X ranges from 0 to 3, corresponding to DMA channels 0 to 3.Before a channel is enabled, its corresponding register must be programmed by software. After the channel is enabled, the register is updated in any of the following cases:
  • The source address is incremented.
  • A complete data block is transferred and then loaded from LLI nodes.If a channel is active, no valid information can be obtained when this register is read. This is because that after software obtains the register value, the value has changed during data transfer. Therefore, this register is read after the channel stops data transfer. At this time, the read value is the last source address read by the DMAC.The source and destination addresses must be aligned with the transfer widths of the source and destination devices.

Member.name: src_addr
Member.description: DMA source address

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_CX_DEST_ADDR
RegisterGroup.description:
a destination address register. Its offset address is 0x104+X*0x20. X ranges from 0 to 3, corresponding to DMA channels 0 to 3.This register contains the destination address (sorted by byte) of the data to be transferred. Before a channel is enabled, its corresponding register must be programmed by software. After the channel is enabled, the register is updated in any of the following cases:
  • The destination address is incremented.
  • A complete data block is transferred and then loaded from LLI nodes.If a channel is active, no valid information can be obtained when this register is read. This is because that after software obtains the register value, the value has changed during data transfer. Therefore, this register is read after the channel stops data transfer. At this time, the read value is the last destination address written by the DMAC.

Member.name: dest_addr
Member.description: DMA destination address

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_CXLLI
RegisterGroup.description:
an LLI register. Its offset address is 0x108+X*0x20. X ranges from 0 to 3, corresponding to DMA channels 0 to 3.The data structure of the DMAC LLI node is as follows:
  • DMAC_CX_SRC_ADDR specifies the start address of the source deviceDMAC_CX_DEST_ADDR specifies the start address of the destination device.
  • DMAC_CXLLI specifies the address of the next nodeDMAC_CX_CONTROL specifies the master, data width, burst size, address increment, and transfer size of the source device and destination device.Structure of the linked list for the DMAC
CAUTIONThe LLI field value must be less than or equal to 0xFFFF_FFF0. Otherwise, the address is wrapped around to 0x0000_0000 during a 4-word burst transfer. As a result, the data structure of LLI nodes cannot be stored in a consecutive address area.If the LLI field is set to 0, the current node is at the end of the linked list. In this case, the corresponding channel is disabled after data blocks corresponding to the current node are transferred.

Member.name: lli
Member.description: LLI. Bit[31:2] in the next LLI node address and the address bit[1:0] are set to 0. A linked list address must be 4-byte aligned.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description: Reserved. This bit value must be set to 0 during write operations and masked during read operations.

Member.name: lm
Member.description:
Master for loading the next LLI node
0: master 1
1: master 2

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_CX_CONTROL
RegisterGroup.description: a channel control register. Its offset address is 0x10C+I*0x20. X ranges from 0 to 3, corresponding to DMA channels 0 to 3.This register contains the control information about the DMA channels, such as the transfer size, burst size, and transfer bit width.Before a channel is enabled, its corresponding register must be programmed by software. After the channel is enabled, the register is updated when being loaded from a linked list node after a complete data block is transferred.If a channel is active, no valid information can be obtained when this register is read. This is because after software obtains the register value, the value has changed during data transfer. Therefore, this register is read after the channel stops data transfer.

Member.name: i
Member.description:
Transfer completion interrupt enable
This bit determines whether the current LLI node triggers a transfer completion interrupt.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: prot
Member.description: HPROT[2:0] access protection signal transmitted by the master

Member.name: di
Member.description:
Destination address increment
0: The destination address is not incremented.
1: The destination address is incremented each time a data segment is transferred.
If the destination device is a peripheral, the destination address is not incremented. If the destination device is a memory, the destination address is incremented.

Member.name: si
Member.description:
Source address increment
0: The source address is not incremented.
1: The source address is incremented each time a data segment is transferred.
If the source device is a peripheral, the source address is not incremented. If the source device is a memory, the source address is incremented.

Member.name: d
Member.description: Master for accessing the destination device

Member.name: s
Member.description: Master for accessing the source device

Member.name: dwidth
Member.description:
Transfer bit width of the destination device
The transfer bit width is invalid if it is greater than the bit width of the master.
The data widths of the destination and source devices can be different. The hardware automatically packs and unpacks the data.
For details about the mapping between the value of DWidth and the bit width, see Table 3-95.

Member.name: swidth
Member.description:
Transfer bit width of the source device
The transfer bit width is invalid if it is greater than the bit width of the master.
The data widths of the destination and source devices can be different. The hardware automatically packs and unpacks the data.
For details about the mapping between the value of SWidth and the bit width, see Table 3-95.

Member.name: dbsize
Member.description:
Burst size of the destination device, indicating the number of data segments to be transferred by the destination device in a burst transfer, that is, the number of transferred data segments when DMACCxBREQ is valid
It must be set to a burst size supported by the destination device. If the destination device is a memory, set it to the storage area size beyond the storage address boundary.
For details about the mapping between the value of DBSize and the transfer size, see Table 3-94.

Member.name: sbsize
Member.description:
Burst size of the source device, indicating the number of data segments to be transferred by the source device in a burst transfer, that is, the number of transferred data segments when DMACCxBREQ is valid
It must be set to a burst size supported by the source device. If the source device is a memory, set it to the storage area size beyond the storage address boundary.
For details about the mapping between the value of SBSize and the transfer size, see table Table 3-95.

Member.name: transfersize
Member.description:
The DMA transfer size can be configured by writing to this register only when the DMAC is a flow controller. This field indicates the amount of data to be transferred by the source device.
When this register is read, the amount of data transferred through the bus connected to the destination device is obtained.
If a channel is active, no valid information can be obtained when this register is read. This is because that after software obtains the register value, the value has changed during data transfer. Therefore, this register is read after the channel is enabled and data transfer stops.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_CX_CONFIG
RegisterGroup.description: a channel configuration register. Its offset address is 0x110+X*0x20. X ranges from 0 to 3, corresponding to DMA channels 0 to 3.This register is not updated when a new linked list node is loaded.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved
This bit must be set to 0 during write operations and masked during read operations.

Member.name: h
Member.description:
Halt bit
0: The DMA request is allowed.
1: The subsequent DMA requests are ignored and data in the channel FIFO is completely transmitted.
This bit can work with the Active bit and the Channel Enable bit to disable a DMA channel without data loss.

Member.name: a
Member.description:
Active bit
0: There is no data in the channel FIFO.
1: There is data in the channel FIFO.
This bit can work with the Halt bit and the Channel Enable bit to disable a DMA channel without data loss.

Member.name: l
Member.description:
Lock bit
0: Disable lock transfer on the bus.
1: Enable lock transfer on the bus.

Member.name: itc
Member.description:
Transfer completion interrupt mask
0: masked
1: not masked

Member.name: ie
Member.description:
Transfer error interrupt mask
0: masked
1: not masked

Member.name: flow_cntrl
Member.description:
Flow control and transfer type
This field specifies the flow controller and transfer type. The flow controller can be the DMAC, source device, or destination device.
The transfer type can be memory to peripheral, peripheral to memory, peripheral to peripheral, or memory to memory. For details, see Table 3-97.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved
This bit must be set to 0 during write operations and masked during read operations.

Member.name: dest_peripheral
Member.description:
Destination device
The field is used to select a peripheral request signal as the request signal for the DMA destination device of the channel.
If the destination device for DMA transfer is a memory, this field is ignored.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved
This bit must be set to 0 during write operations and masked during read operations.

Member.name: src_peripheral
Member.description:
Source device
This field is used to select a peripheral request signal as the request signal for the DMA source device of the channel.
If the source device for DMA transfer is a memory, this field is ignored.

Member.name: e
Member.description:
Channel enable
Reading this field obtains the current channel status.
0: disabled
1: enabled
Clearing this bit can disable a channel. When this bit is cleared, the current bus transfer continues until the data transfer is complete. Then, the channel is disabled and the remaining data in the FIFO is lost. When the last LLI node is transferred or an error occurs during transfer, the channel is also disabled and this bit is cleared. If you want to disable a channel without data loss, the Halt bit must be set to 1 so that the subsequent DMA requests are ignored by the channel. After this, the Active bit must be polled until its value becomes 0, indicating that there is no data in the channel FIFO. At this time, the Enable bit can be cleared.
To enable a channel by setting this bit to 1, you must reinitialize the channel. If a channel is enabled by setting this bit to 1 only, unexpected results may occur.

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_LOAD
RegisterGroup.description: an initial count value register. It is used to configure the initial count value for the internal counter of the watchdog.

Member.name: wdg_load
Member.description: Initial count value

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_VALUE
RegisterGroup.description: a current count value register. It is used to read the current count value of the internal counter of the watchdog.

Member.name: wdogvalue
Member.description: Current count value of the watchdog counter

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_CONTROL
RegisterGroup.description: a control register. It is used to enable or disable the watchdog and control the interrupt and reset functions.

Member.name: resen
Member.description:
Output enable of the watchdog reset signal
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: inten
Member.description:
Output enable of the watchdog interrupt signal
0: The counter stops counting, the current count value remains unchanged, and the watchdog is disabled.
1: Both the counter and the interrupt are enabled. In addition, the watchdog is enabled.

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_INTCLR
RegisterGroup.description: an interrupt clear register. It is used to clear watchdog interrupts so that the watchdog can reload an initial value for counting. This register is write-only. Writing any value to this register clears the watchdog interrupts. No written value is recorded in this register and no default reset value is defined.

Member.name: wdg_intclr
Member.description: Writing any value to this register clears the watchdog interrupts and enables the watchdog to reload an initial count value from WDG_LOAD to restart counting.

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_RIS
RegisterGroup.description: a raw interrupt register. It shows the raw interrupt status of the watchdog.

Member.name: wdogris
Member.description:
Raw watchdog interrupt status. When the count value decreases to 0, this bit is set to 1.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_MIS
RegisterGroup.description: a masked interrupt register. It shows the masked interrupt status of the watchdog.

Member.name: wdogmis
Member.description:
Masked watchdog interrupt status
0: No interrupt is generated or the interrupt is masked.
1: An interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: WDG_LOCK
RegisterGroup.description: a lock register. It is used to control the write and read permission for the watchdog registers.

Member.name: wdg_lock
Member.description:
Writing 0x1ACC_E551 to this register enables the write permission for all watchdog registers.
Writing any value except 0x1ACC_E551 disables the write permission for all watchdog registers.
Reading this register returns the lock status but not the value written to this register.
0x0000_0000: The write access is allowed (unlocked).
0x0000_0001: The write access is not allowed (locked).

RegisterGroup.name: GPIO_DATA
RegisterGroup.description:
a GPIO data register. It is used to buffer the input or output data.When the corresponding bit of GPIO_DIR is configured as output, the values written to GPIO_DATA are output to the corresponding pin (ensure that the configuration of pin multiplexing is correct). If the bit is configured as input, the value of the corresponding input pin is read.CAUTIONWhen the corresponding bits of GPIO_DIR are set to inputs, the pin values are returned if the read operation is valid. When the corresponding bits are set to outputs, the written values are returned if the read operation is valid.The GPIO_DATA register masks the read and write operations on bits by using PADDR[9:2]. This register corresponds to 256 address spaces. PADDR[9:2] correspond to GPIO_DATA[7:0]. When a PADDR bit is high, the corresponding bit in GPIO_DATA can be read or written; when the corresponding bit is low, the read or write operation is not allowed. For example:
  • If the address is 0x3FC (0b11_1111_1100), operations on all the eight bits of GPIO_DATA[7:0] are valid.
  • If the address is 0x200 (0b10_0000_0000), the operation on only GPIO_DATA[7] is valid.

Member.name: gpio_data
Member.description:
GPIO input data when the GPIO is configured as input or GPIO output data when the GPIO is configured as output
Each bit can be separately controlled. This register works with GPIO_DIR.

RegisterGroup.name: GPIO_DIR
RegisterGroup.description: a GPIO direction control register. It is used to configure the direction of each GPIO pin.

Member.name: gpio_dir
Member.description:
GPIO direction control. Bit[7:0] correspond to GPIO_DATA bit[7:0] respectively. Each bit can be separately controlled.
0: input
1: output

RegisterGroup.name: GPIO_IS
RegisterGroup.description: a GPIO interrupt trigger mode register. It is used to configure the interrupt trigger mode.

Member.name: gpio_is
Member.description:
GPIO interrupt trigger mode. Bit[7:0] correspond to GPIO_DATA bit[7:0] respectively. Each bit can be separately controlled.
0: edge-sensitive mode
1: level-sensitive mode

RegisterGroup.name: GPIO_IBE
RegisterGroup.description: a GPIO interrupt edge control register. It is used to configure the edge trigger mode of each GPIO pin.

Member.name: gpio_ibe
Member.description:
GPIO interrupt edge control. Bit[7:0] correspond to GPIO_DATA[7:0] respectively. Each bit can be separately controlled.
0: single-edge-sensitive mode. GPIO_IEV controls whether the interrupt is rising-edge-sensitive or falling-edge-sensitive.
1: dual-edge-sensitive mode

RegisterGroup.name: GPIO_IEV
RegisterGroup.description: a GPIO interrupt trigger event register. It is used to configure the interrupt trigger event of a GPIO pin.

Member.name: gpio_iev
Member.description:
GPIO interrupt trigger event. Bit[7:0] correspond to GPIO_DATA bit[7:0] respectively. Each bit can be separately controlled.
0: The interrupt is triggered by the falling edge or low level.
1: The interrupt is triggered by the rising edge or high level.

RegisterGroup.name: GPIO_IE
RegisterGroup.description: a GPIO interrupt mask register. It is used to mask GPIO interrupts.

Member.name: gpio_ie
Member.description:
GPIO interrupt mask. Bit[7:0] correspond to GPIO_DATA bit[7:0] respectively. Each bit can be separately controlled.
0: masked
1: not masked

RegisterGroup.name: GPIO_RIS
RegisterGroup.description: a GPIO raw interrupt status register. It is used to query the raw interrupt status of each GPIO pin.

Member.name: gpio_ris
Member.description:
GPIO raw interrupt status. Bit[7:0] correspond to GPIO_DATA bit[7:0] respectively, indicating the unmasked interrupt status. This status is not under the mask control of the GPIO_IE register.
1: An interrupt is generated.
0: No interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: GPIO_MIS
RegisterGroup.description: a GPIO masked interrupt status register. It is used to query the masked interrupt status of each GPIO pin.

Member.name: gpio_mis
Member.description:
GPIO masked interrupt status. Bit[7:0] correspond to GPIO_DATA bit[7:0] respectively, indicating the masked interrupt status. This status can be masked and controlled by the GPIO_IE register.
0: The interrupt is invalid.
1: The interrupt is valid.

RegisterGroup.name: GPIO_IC
RegisterGroup.description: a GPIO interrupt clear register. It is used to clear the GPIO_RIS and GPIO_MIS registers and interrupts generated by GPIO pins.

Member.name: gpio_ic
Member.description:
GPIO interrupt clear. Bit[7:0] correspond to GPIO_DATA bit[7:0] respectively. Each bit can be separately controlled.
0: not cleared
1: cleared

RegisterGroup.name: IR_EN
RegisterGroup.description: an IR RX enable control register.CAUTIONBefore configuring other registers, set IR_EN[ir_en] to 1 by using software. Otherwise, configuring other registers has no effect. When IR_EN[ir_en] is 0, other registers are read-only and the read values are their reset values.

Member.name: ir_en
Member.description:
IR RX enable
0: disabled
1: enabled

RegisterGroup.name: IR_CFG
RegisterGroup.description:
an IR configuration register.CAUTIONBefore setting this register, ensure that IR_BUSY[ir_busy] is set to 0 and IR_EN[ir_en] is set to 1. Otherwise, the original value is retained after setting.The reference clock frequency supported by the IR module ranges from 1 MHz to 128 MHz. The following describes the relationship between the frequency and the clock divider ir_freq:
  • When the reference clock frequency is 1 MHz, ir_freq must be set to 0x00.
  • When the reference clock frequency is 128 MHz, ir_freq must be set to 0x7F.When the frequency of the IR reference clock ranging from 1 MHz to 128 MHz is not an integer, the clock divider is selected based on the rounded reference clock frequency. For example, if the reference clock frequency is 12.1 MHz, the clock divider is 0x0B; if the reference clock frequency is 12.8 MHz, the clock divider is 0x0C.The following describes the relationship between the frequency offset and the count deviation. If the base frequency is f and the frequency variation is Df, the frequency offset ratio is Df/f. If the count deviation of the counter is Dcnt, and the judge level width is s (in μs), the count deviation Dcnt is calculated as follows: Dcnt = 0.1 x s x ratio. Therefore, when the clock has frequency offset, the valid range of the parameter value needs to be shifted. If the frequency increases, the corresponding margin range is changed to [min + Dcnt, max + Dcnt], where min and max indicate the margins without frequency offset. If the frequency decreases, the offset range is changed to [min ? Dcnt, max ? Dcnt]. Take the margin of the start bit in the lead code as an example. If the base frequency is 100 MHz, and the frequency increases by 0.1 MHz, the ratio is 0.001 (0.1/100). If s is 9000 μs, Dcnt is calculated as follows: Dcnt = 0.1 x 9000 x 0.001 = 1. In this case, the margin range of ir_leads must be changed to [0x033D, 0x3CD].

Member.name: ir_max_level_width
Member.description:
Invalid when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0
Maximum level width (in 10 μs) of a symbol when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 1. This width identifies the end of a symbol stream.

Member.name: ir_format
Member.description:
Data code format when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0
00: NEC with simple repeat code
01: TC9012 code
10: NEC with full repeat code
11: SONY code
For details about the relationship between code types and code formats, see Table 11-11 to Table 11-13.
Symbol format when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 1
Bit[15]: reserved
Bit[14]:
0: The symbol is from low to high, and the symbol stream ends at the high level.
1: The symbol is from high to low, and the symbol stream ends at the low level.

Member.name: ir_bits
Member.description:
Number of data bits in a frame when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0
0x00–0x2F: correspond to bit 1 to bit 48 in a frame respectively
0x30?0x3F: reserved
If ir_bits is set to a value ranging from 0x30 to 0x3F by using software, the setting has no effect and the original value is retained.
Symbol RX interrupt threshold when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 1
Bit[13:8]: 0x0–0x3F. 0x0 indicates that an interrupt is reported when there is at least one symbol in the FIFO, 0x3F indicates that an interrupt is reported when there are at least 64 symbols in the FIFO, and so on.

Member.name: ir_mode
Member.description:
IR operating mode
0: The decoded complete data frames are output.
1: Only the symbol width is output.

Member.name: ir_freq
Member.description:
Working clock divider
0x00–0x7F correspond to the clock divider 1–128 respectively.

RegisterGroup.name: IR_LEADS
RegisterGroup.description:
a lead code start bit margin configuration register (valid only when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0).CAUTIONBefore setting this register, ensure that IR_BUSY[ir_busy] is set to 0 and IR_EN[ir_en] is set to 1. Otherwise, the original value is retained after setting.The margin must be considered based on the typical value of the specific code type for accurately determining the start bit of the lead code. For details about the typical values of specified code types, see the values of LEAD_S in Table 11-11 to Table 11-13.
  • For the pulse width whose typical value is greater than or equal to 400 (10 μs precision), the recommended margin is 8% of the typical value. For example, if the typical value of LEAD_S for D6121 is 900, the value of cnt_leads_min is 0x33C (900 x 92% = 828), and the value of cnt_leads_max is 0x3CC (900 x 108% = 972).
  • For the pulse width whose typical value is less than 400 (10 μs precision), the recommended margin is 20% of the typical value. For example, if the typical value of LEAD_S for SONY-D7C5 is 240, the value of cnt_leads_min is 0xC0 (240 x 80% = 192), and the value of cnt_leads_max is 0x120 (240 x 120% = 288).The basic configuration principles are as follows: cnt_leads_max is greater than or equal to cnt_leads_min, and cnt_leads_min is greater than cnt0_b_max and cnt1_b_max.

Member.name: cnt_leads_min
Member.description:
Minimum pulse width of the start bit of the lead code
0x000?0x007: reserved

Member.name: cnt_leads_max
Member.description:
Maximum pulse width of the start bit of the lead code
0x000?0x007: reserved

RegisterGroup.name: IR_LEADE
RegisterGroup.description:
a lead code end bit margin configuration register (valid only when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0).CAUTION
  • Before configuring this register, ensure that IR_BUSY[ir_busy] is set to 0 and IR_EN[ir_en] is set to 1. Otherwise, the original value is retained after configuration.
  • For the NEC with simple repeat codes, the margins of cnt_sleade and cnt_leade cannot overlap. Otherwise, when the actual count value falls within the overlap range, the simple lead code cannot be identified. As a result, a frame format error occurs.The margin must be considered based on the typical value of the specific code type for accurately determining the end bit of the lead code. The margin is about 8% of the typical value. For details about the typical values of specific code types, see the values of LEAD_E in Table 11-11 to Table 11-13.
  • For the pulse width whose typical value is greater than or equal to 400 (10 μs precision), the recommended margin is 8% of the typical value. For example, if the typical value of LEAD_E for D6121 is 450, the value of cnt_leade_min is 0x19E (450 x 92% = 414), and the value of cnt_leade_max is 0x1E6 (450 x 108% = 486).
  • For the pulse width whose typical value is less than 400 (10 μs precision), the recommended margin is 20% of the typical value. For example, if the typical value of LEAD_E for SONY-D7C5 is 60, the value of cnt_leade_min is 0x030 (60 x 80% = 48), and the value of cnt_leade_max is 0x048 (60 x 120% = 72).The basic configuration principle is that cnt_leade_max must be greater than or equal to cnt_leade_min.

Member.name: cnt_leade_min
Member.description:
Minimum pulse width of the end bit of the lead code
0x000?0x007: reserved

Member.name: cnt_leade_max
Member.description:
Maximum pulse width of the end bit of the lead code
0x000?0x007: reserved

RegisterGroup.name: IR_SLEADE
RegisterGroup.description:
a simple lead code end bit margin configuration register (valid only when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0).CAUTION
  • Before setting this register, ensure that IR_BUSY[ir_busy] is set to 0 and IR_EN[ir_en] is set to 1. Otherwise, the original value is retained after setting.
  • For the NEC with simple repeat codes, the margins of cnt_sleade and cnt_leade cannot overlap. Otherwise, when the actual count value falls within the overlap range, the simple lead code cannot be identified. As a result, a frame format error occurs.
  • This register needs to be configured only for the NEC with simple repeat code.The margin must be considered based on the typical value of the specific code type for accurately determining the end bit of the simple lead code. For details about the typical values of specific code types, see the values of SLEAD_E in Table 11-11 to Table 11-13.For a pulse width whose typical value is greater than or equal to 225 (10 μs precision), the recommended margin is 8% of the typical value. For example, if the typical value of SLEAD_E for D6121 is 225, the value of cnt_sleade_min is 0xCF (225 x 92% = 207), and the value of cnt_sleade_max is 0xF3 (225 x 108% = 243). For a pulse width whose typical value is less than 225 (10 μs precision), the recommended margin is 20% of the typical value. For example, if the typical value of SLEAD_E for a code is 60, the value of cnt_sleade_min is 0x030 (60 x 80% = 48), and the value of cnt_sleade_max is 0x048 (60 x 120% = 72).The basic configuration principle is that cnt_sleade_max must be greater than or equal to cnt_sleade_min.

Member.name: cnt_sleade_min
Member.description:
Minimum pulse width of the end bit of the simple lead code
0x000?0x007: reserved

Member.name: cnt_sleade_max
Member.description:
Maximum pulse width of the start bit of the simple lead code
0x000?0x007: reserved

RegisterGroup.name: IR_B0
RegisterGroup.description:
a data 0 level judge margin configuration register (valid only when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0).CAUTION
  • Before setting this register, ensure that IR_BUSY[ir_busy] is set to 0 and set IR_EN[ir_en] is set to 1. Otherwise, the original value is retained after setting.
  • The level judge margin ranges for bit 0 and bit 1 of the four types of codes cannot overlap. Otherwise, when the actual count value falls within the overlap range, bit 1 cannot be identified and is regarded as bit 0 by mistake.The margin must be considered based on the typical value of the specific code type for accurately determining bit 0. The margin is about 20% of the typical value.
  • For details about the typical values of the NEC with simple repeat code, NEC with simple repeat code, and TC9012 code, see the values of B0_H in Table 11-11 to Table 11-13cnt0_b_min is 0x2D (56 x 80% = 45), and cnt0_b_max is 0x43 (56 x 120% = 67).
  • For details about the typical values of SONY codes, see the values of B0_L in Table 11-11μs precision), cnt0_b_min is 0x30 (60 x 80% = 48), and cnt0_b_max is 0x48 (60 x 120% = 72).The basic configuration principle is that cnt0_b_max must be greater than or equal to cnt0_b_min.

Member.name: cnt0_b_min
Member.description:
Minimum pulse width of the level for determining bit 0
0x000?0x007: reserved

Member.name: cnt0_b_max
Member.description:
Maximum pulse width of the level for determining bit 0
0x000?0x007: reserved

RegisterGroup.name: IR_B1
RegisterGroup.description:
a data 1 judge level margin configuration register (valid only when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0).CAUTION
  • Before configuring this register, ensure that IR_BUSY[ir_busy] is set to 0 and IR_EN[ir_en] is set to 1. Otherwise, the original value is retained after configuration.
  • The level judge margin ranges for bit 0 and bit 1 of the four types of codes cannot overlap. Otherwise, when the actual count value falls within the overlap range, bit 1 cannot be identified and is regarded as bit 0 by mistake.The margin must be considered based on the typical value of the specific code type for accurately determining bit 1. The margin is about 20% of the typical value.
  • For details about the typical values of the NEC with simple repeat code, NEC with simple repeat code, and TC9012 code, see the values of B1_H in Table 11-11 to Table 11-13cnt1_b_min is 0x87 (169 x 80% = 135), and cnt1_b_max is 0xCB (169 x 120% = 203).
  • For details about the typical values of SONY codes, see the values of B1_L in Table 11-11μs precision), cnt1_b_min is 0x60 (120 x 80% = 96), and cnt1_b_max is 0x90 (120 x 120% = 144).The basic configuration principle is that cnt1_b_max must be greater than or equal to cnt1_b_min.

Member.name: cnt1_b_min
Member.description:
Minimum pulse width of the level for determining bit 1
0x000?0x007: reserved

Member.name: cnt1_b_max
Member.description:
Maximum pulse width of the level for determining bit 1
0x000?0x007: reserved

RegisterGroup.name: IR_BUSY
RegisterGroup.description: a configuration busy flag register.

Member.name: ir_busy
Member.description:
Busy status flag
0: idle. Software can configure data.
1: busy. Software cannot configure data.

RegisterGroup.name: IR_DATAH
RegisterGroup.description: an upper 16-bit IR RX decoded data register (when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0) or symbol FIFO symbol count register (when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 1).When IR_CFG[ir_mode] is set to 0, IR_DATAH receives the upper 16 bits of the decoded data, whereas IR_DATAL receives the lower 32 bits of the decoded data. The valid data bits depend on the number of valid data bits in a frame of specific code. For details, see the valid data bits in Table 11-11 to Table 11-13.Data is stored in IR_DATAL and then IR_DATAH from LSB to MSB. That is, after IR_DATAL is full, the remaining data is stored in IR_DATAH. The unused upper bits are reserved. Software must read IR_DATAH before IR_DATAL.When IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 1, hardware receives all data bits without considering the definition of each data bit. Then software processes the data bits in a unified manner.

Member.name: ir_datah
Member.description:
Upper 16 bits of the decoded data received by the IR module when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0
Number of symbols in the symbol FIFO when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 1
Bit[15:7]: reserved
Bit[6:0]: number of symbols in the symbol FIFO

RegisterGroup.name: IR_DATAL
RegisterGroup.description: a lower 32-bit IR RX decoded data register (when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0) or IR received symbol width register (when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 1).

Member.name: ir_datal
Member.description:
Lower 32 bits of the decoded data received by the IR module when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0
Width of the symbol received by the IR module when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 1
Bit[31:16]:
When the symbol is low and then high, these bits indicate the high-level width (in 10 μs) of the symbol received by the IR module.
When the symbol is high and then low, these bits indicate the low-level width (in 10 μs) of the symbol received by the IR module.
Bit[15:0]:
When the symbol is low and then high, these bits indicate the low-level width (in 10 μs) of the symbol received by the IR module.
When the symbol is high and then low, these bits indicate the high-level width (in 10 μs) of the symbol received by the IR module.

RegisterGroup.name: IR_INT_MASK
RegisterGroup.description:
an IR interrupt mask register.CAUTION
  • Before setting this register, ensure that IR_EN[ir_en] is set to 1. Otherwise, the original value is retained after setting.
  • If all interrupts are masked, the IR wakeup function is unavailable.
  • When IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 0, IR_INT_MASK bit[3:0] are valid; when IR_CFG[ir_mode] is 1, IR_INT_MASK bit[18:16] are valid.The following describes related interrupts:
  • RX data overflow interrupt
    • If the CPU does not fetch the current frame in time and the subsequent frame is received, the subsequent frame overwrites the current frame, and a raw RX data overflow interrupt is reported.
  • RX data frame format error interrupt
    • If the received data frame is incomplete or the data pulse width does not full within the margin range, a raw RX frame format error interrupt is reported.
  • Data frame RX interrupt
    • When a complete frame is received, a raw data frame RX interrupt is reported.
  • Key release detection interrupt
    • For the NEC with simple repeat code and TC9012 code data formats, if the start sync code is not detected again within 160 ms after the previous start sync code is detected, or a valid data frame rather than a simple lead code is detected, a raw key release detection interrupt is reported. The key release detection interrupt is not supported for the NEC with full repeat code and the SONY code.
  • RX symbol overflow interrupt
    • If the symbol FIFO is full because the CPU does not fetch the data in time and the subsequent symbol is already received, a raw RX symbol overflow interrupt is reported.
  • Symbol RX interrupt
    • If a complete symbol is received and the number of symbols in the symbol FIFO is above the threshold specified in IR_CFG[ir_bits], a raw symbol RX interrupt is reported.
  • Symbol timeout interrupt
    • If no symbol is received during the period configured in IR_CFG[ir_max_level_width] after a valid symbol is received, a raw symbol timeout interrupt is reported.Hardware does not identify the interrupt priority. An interrupt is generated if one or more masked interrupt sources are valid.

Member.description:

0: not masked
1: masked

Member.description:

RegisterGroup.name: SCI_DATA
RegisterGroup.description: an SCI data register. It is used to transmit or receive characters and serves as the data interface between the SCI and software.The software can write to the register only after SCI_CR1[mode] is set to 1. If SCI_CR1[mode] is set to 0, writing to this register has no effect.

Member.name: parity
Member.description:
Parity check error flag
This bit is transmitted with data during data transmission. During data reception, software checks whether parity check is correct based on the value of this bit.
0: correct
1: incorrect

Member.name: scidata
Member.description: 8-bit data to be read or written

RegisterGroup.name: SCI_CR0
RegisterGroup.description:
SCI control register 0. It is used to control the information such as clock enable, parity check, transfer handshake, and transfer bit definition.CAUTIONSCI_CR0[paritybit] controls whether to enable the parity check function during data transmission or reception. When this bit is set to 0, the received or transmitted frame does not contain the parity bit. According to the T0 or T1 protocol, this bit must be set to 1.
  • SCI_CR0[clkdis] and SCI_CR0[clkval] control whether to enable the smart card clock and configure the state of the clock pin after the clock is disabled.
  • SCI_CR0[rxnak] and SCI_CR0[txnak] control whether to enable the handshake mechanisms between the SCI and the smart card. A handshake is implemented when the RX end pulls down the data line (I/O) to request the TX end to retransmit characters after detecting a parity check error in the data sent from the TX end. The handshake mechanisms for data transmission and reception are separately enabled. The maximum retransmission times during data transmission or reception is defined by SCI_RETRY. During ATR reception, character retransmission is not allowed; therefore, the handshake mechanism must be disabled by setting the corresponding TX or RX control bit to 0.
  • SCI_CR0[rxparity] and SCI_CR0[txparity] control the parity check mode during data reception and transmission respectively.According to the direct convention, the low level of the data line (I/O) indicates logic 0 and the least significant bit (LSB) of data is after the start bit of a frame. If SCI_CR0 bit[1:0] is set to 0b00, the direct convention is selected.According to the inverse convention, the low level of the data line (I/O) indicates logic 1 and the most significant bit (MSB) of data is after the start bit of a frame. If SCI_CR0 bit[1:0] is set to 0b11, the inverse convention is selected.
NOTE
  • The character bit sequence and inversion of the data and parity bits can be separately configured. These features enable the SCI to support non-standard protocols (non-direct convention or non-inverse convention).
  • Before the start TS character of the ATR is received, SCI_CR0 bit[1:0] must be set to 0b00.

Member.description:
Valid level for the detected input signal
0: active high
1: active low

Member.name: vccen_inv
Member.description:
Valid level for the vccen output signal

1: active low

Parity check mode control in RX mode

1: odd parity check

Member.name: txnak

1: odd parity check

1: The SCI detects data and parity bits on the I/O line after inversion.
